name: The Yawhg
description: The Yawhg is a one-to-four player choose-your-own-adventure game that randomizes a unique story every time you play. The evil Yawhg is returning. How will the townâ€™s locals lead their lives in the meanwhile, and what will they do when the dreaded Yawhg finally arrives?
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Memory: 2 GB RAM DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 100 MB available space Additional Notes: A resolution of at least 1280 x 720.

reviews.review_text: What a great game. A few beers, sit around and yell about how magnificent you are. And it goes fast, so even better for drinking. What I'm trying to say is, this game is gorgeous, it sounds great, and it gets me drunk. Really good and drunk.  10/10, would drink again.

I played the Yawhg a couple of times, and I must say it is quite an amusing game. It's all pretty straight-forward: you and/or your friends each choose a character (you can also choose characters yourself and play the game on your own) and choose a location you wish to go to. Each location has a couple of options on actions you can perform, such as cutting wood, tending to patients, and yes, even getting drunk! But beware: each choice you make might positively or negatively affect your stats. After a couple of turns, the mysterious Yawhg happens and each person will have to choose a role which fits their character's stats best (or you can do the opposite, and watch the outcome!), after which you'll get to know whether your town survived, and -more importantly- how your characters pick up their life again afterwards.  The Yawhg is a funny little game which you can play with friends. The graphics are all really fitting and nice, the music is simple, yet suits the game and the absolute highlight of the game is the amount of choices you can make, and the randomnized events you'll encounter. However, the game is VERY short. Almost too short. And that, in my humble opinion, is the only thing where it falls short, for me personally. However, the replay value is very big.   Get it during a sale, or if you like experimental choice-heavy little games like this one.  All in all, 7/10

The only reason I don't recommend this game is that it literally only takes ten minutes to play through it, and only a couple of replays and you'll figure out how to get a perfect ending for whatever roles you choose at the end. I played it for less than an hour total and i'm done with it for good. It's a neat concept though.

I was apparently terrible at being a mage and ended up burning all my hair off at a party. Complete laughingstock. But then I became a werewolf, a crime-fighter, and a gladiator, rebuilt the town after the Yawhg wrecked the place, and ended up becoming a friendly lumberjack.  I'm a lumberjack and I'm okay.  Next, I became a powerful mage who could level buildings with a word and conjure magnificent supplies ot rebuild the town.  But that couldn't save me the heartache of losing contact with a dear friend.

This was really a waste of money. Don't get me wrong, I like the visuals, but the actual gameplay is just so short. I expected more from this. If it's on sale, you should get it but don't pay the full price for it.

I wouldn't recommend this game at full price. After reading the reviews, I thought 'The Yawhg' was going to be an exciting adventure story. I, personally, go to games based on their stories. Seeing this one tagged 'Story Rich' caught my attention, and I figured, 'Hey, why not give it a go?'. I was extremely disappointed.. It was not at all exciting. Overall, it just felt flat and boring. The only things I really felt were at all worth it about this game were the music and the art style. The compositions were impressive, but that was the extent of my satisfaction with the game. I suppose this game could be fun if you invited over a couple of friends and played it drunk with people, but still, I would not recommend investing the $10 on this game... It's just not worth it.

I've played The Yawhg twice on my own and twice with a friend and had a blast every time! It's a really simple concept: something bad's going to happen in six weeks, but you're not going to worry about that, there's hunting to do in the forest, patients to tend at the hospital, and malicious hedges to confront! You play a minimum of two characters (up to four) playing with friends is as easy as passing the keyboard (or controller) back and forth. Gameplay is simple, you choose an area of the city that you want to spend your week at, and then you choose what you want to do at that location. For instance, at the palace, you can choose to do administration work or attend a ball. Each activity will raise different stats (physique, finesse, charm, mind, magic, wealth). Random events at each location will also raise or lower certain stats, often, you will be asked to make a choice during these events. Whether you pass or fail seems to depend on stats some of the time and on random rolls other times. The game mixes comedy and horror in a way that reminds me of Welcome to Night Vale with a pinch of Princess Maker 2 and the art style of Don't Starve or a Roald Dahl book. It's funny, dark, and at times very disturbing, and it frequently flip flops between funny and horrifying moments in the space of seconds (the endings are particularly prone to this). Yes, The Yawhg is pretty short, a single playthrough can take anywhere from ten to twenty minutes (or longer if you're playing with friends) and you will be seeing repeat events quite often, but the game has a ton of different endings, and each playthrough tells a different story.  In short, if you like interactive fiction, a bit of comedy with your horror, or maybe you're just looking for something unique, The Yawhg is well worth the full price.

The Yawhg is a great story-telling game with a interesting plot, especially for first time players who have no clue as to what the Yawhg is. The game is quite replayble due its multiplul possible endings, based on your decisions, If you enjoy 'choose your own adventure' games, then this is definetley for you.
Best party game we have played in awhile

The fact that it is possible to complete this very halfassed game in 10 minutes is pretty much the reason you should not spend the 10 buck asking price for it. Are they kidding? What on EARTH makes them think a random game with little gameplay involved is going to be worth 10 dollars?  Here's the game. You pick anywhere from 1-4 characters. You send them to a random location, get a random stat increase, which, considering there is no battle system whatsoever, is merely to decide how successful you are at future random stat increases... then 6 turns later, you choose a profession for your character(s), and the game decides if you were lucky enough to merit a happy or sad ending. Pretty lame, huh? Control wise? If you alt tab out of the game to lower the volume because the music gets really dull after awhile, the game crashes. And there is no option to mute in game. In fact, no option menu at ALL! You can play it, or play something else. This game doesn't WANT to be muted or windowed or any of that. That is frankly, an insult to gamers. I should be able to reduce the loud volume of your game. That's just standard practice, you terrible programmers you.  Look, for further reasons not to get this game? Zoe Quinn is listed in their thank you section when you complete the game. If that isn't a reason to run far the hell away from this game, I don't know what is. Don't even bother to wait for a sale, no amount of money makes this worth a look. Even at a 90% discount, you're still looking at a buck for this, and a buck is like 99 cents too expensive for a 10 minute reading exercise. It's not even worth the trading cards. Skip this with extreme prejudice.
There is no option to change the resolution. If your monitor does not support the game, you are left unable to play.

This game is a great example of how there are no true quality metrics in video game design. Graphics? This game is entirely un-animated and the still images consist completely of low-res cartoons. Gameplay? You pick options off a menu. Music? One guitar. Story? You will finish it in less than a half hour.  And yet The Yawhg is probably worth twice its $10 asking price. In a market saturated with 'gameplay advancements,' '4K resolution,' 'roleplaying elements,' and hundred-hour lengths, very few game developers stop to ask themselves whether they are using these tools to do something worth doing. The Yawhg does something worth doing and does not need any of these tools to do it.  To nitpick the game's description, The Yawhg is not a 'Choose Your Own Adventure.' Choose Your Own Adventure books very rarely had multiple main characters or stats to track. The Yawhg is a /Gamebook,/ and while these were great fun in the 80s before we had real branching-path video games, today this is the best possible format for the medium. The Yawhg is a perfect example of the synergy of right tools and right task, and it is worth the time of anyone who enjoys a good interactive story. I suppose you might call this a visual novel -- I don't know, really, I feel like genre has become largely irrelevant in describing video games.  The story of The Yawhg is different every time you play it, so I can't comment on its quality universally, but if you find yourself telling a story you don't care for, it will only last for 20 more minutes. Suck it up and then start a new one. I still recommend you finish the playthrough, however, because what comes to pass may surprise you.  More like this, please, industry. More like this.
A fun adventure game with many story aspects and great replayability! A very nice game to play when your bored.

Initially, when I first heard of this game, I just figured, 'hey, this looks kinda neat but I'm not paying $10 for it becuase I'm a lousy cheap-â™¥â™¥â™¥.' It looked like a cool concept to me and if it looks like a cool concept to you, then you're perhaps in for something of a treat.  Now, when I first played it on my own, I wasn't particularly entertained. I mean, yes, the different story paths were somewhat interesting and the various different endings were kinda cool but I wasn't really absorbed into it. It was just something I used to make a good 45 minutes pass by one day when I was feeling bored. Then, while with some friends the other night, I decided to pull it out because we all needed a game to play and this just so happened to be multiplayer and seemed like a nice change of pace from the usual stuff we always tend to play (e.g. Genital Jousting, Jackbox Party Pack, etc.) What I didn't expect was for us to keep playing over and over again for several more hours, as we found ourselves unusually entertained by this strange little game.  This is because where The Yawhg shines is in its multiplayer gameplay. As you each play through the runs as your individual character, you become attached to the story and are actually quite affected by the events that happen to you. Trying not to spoil any of the specific events as that would take away from your game experience overall, I will say that each event is quite interesting when it first happens. You feel fear, shock, and surprise as you're faced with various choices, unsure of their meaning or where they lead but finding yourself satisfied by the game's clever use of various fantasy cliches to create a coherent story for your character. But it's in this that the game's largest flaw lies. See, there's only a limited number of events that occur, and, though the game is likely designed to be played in sets of multiple consecutive runs, after a few playthroughs you start to see events repeat and they lose the impact that they originally had on the player. No longer does the story really have any sort of impact, and instead you begin picking choices just to try to get a different ending and experimenting, skipping through the game's incredibly creative dialogue and just rushing through each run. It's still enjoyable in a way, but it's a much less interesting experience as the game goes on and on which I was disappointed by to some extent.  The gameplay itself is quite simple. The game is more or less a choose-your-own-adventure book, and thus you play it by simply making choices on where to go, what to do, and how to react to the random event that always occurs. The gameplay is there to simply give the player choice, immersing them in the story that the game crafts and presents, and in that regard it succeeds. I truly don't think this game is for everyone, and if you're the type of person who's driven by a 'win-lose' sort of mindset then this game might not necessarily appeal to you in terms of how it plays, because the enjoyment is not through feeling as though you 'won' the game. It's through that feeling of autonomy and choice, the decision it grants that makes the player feel unique and able. It does, essentially, what it's supposed to do. The characters will recieved stat boosts that affect their decisions throughout the course of each run, and once you learn what different actions give you then there is some thinking that may go into character building in whatnot, but it's really not sophisticated enough to become the main draw of the game.  Graphically the game is quite appealing. The art is drawn cute but not excessively so, and the visuals are primarily presented in a still-painting format that simply serves to accompany the text as opposed to distracting from it, which I thought was a good design decision. The art style is haunting in a way, matching the somber yet somehow mildly humorous nature of this game. Truly, The Yawhg is not a particularly happy game, and it may give you chills if you're not ready for some of what it presents, and the art style adds greatly to this. Musically, the game has a very relaxing, quiet soundtrack, but I was bothered by the fact that often times it consisted of little 6-second loops playing over and over again as the players went through their days. It accompanies the game well enough but the fact that I could hear it looping was quite bothersome. However, there is a full track that plays at the end and beginning of every run that is so intensely haunting and emotional that my friends and I all found ourselves quite affected by it playing.  Essentially, the Yawhg is not a game that you'll find yourself playing very often if you do decide to buy it, which is something that you probably should keep in mind when making your purchase. Rather, it's a game that you'll pull out from time to time when you have enough time to forget many of the random events and are able to experience them fully again. Also, it's WAY better with friends. Trust me.

Wanted this game for a while, finally got it. I found the game to be fun, but I wish it had more to it. It is very short, but it has replayability which is a plus. I got a bit over an hour of fun from it, and will probably play it a bit more later. If you like 'choose your own adventure' games, and dont mind the game being very short, you should give it a try :)

Ok so, here's the thing. The Yawhg isn't a bad game, in fact the ideas behind the game and the execution are very sound. The problem is that this really shouldn't be a paid product. The Yawhg feels and plays like a free flash game, and ironicly is no where near as good as other Flash games of this type.   Unlike the interactive fiction games you find on Kongrigate The Yawhg isn't really a single player game, rather is basicly a digital Cards vs. Humanity type experience (i hope that makes sense). The Yawhg is turnbased, with each turn repersenting a week Players take turns selecting what they will do on any given week, after 7 weeks a great disaster (the titualr Yawhg) will befall the city and using the skills you've learned throughout the last 7 weeks will try to repair the town in the best way you can. the idea being that the event's pre-Yawhg will be so wacky that players will be able to laugh and have a good time and all the post-Yawhg stuff will be really sad and dramatic. In practice though it's horibly broken, the way the game is structured with it's stat system means that after about one playthrough you'll have no problem easily maxing out a stat to win at the end. This would be fine if the random events at the core of the game kept you guessing, but they don't. Not because there bad or anything but because there are so few of them. I bet that if you played the game with four players one you would see everything this game had to offer. So in other words the game has no replay value what so ever and in the end for a game that costs $10 that's unacceptable.  It may sound like The Yawhg is the worst thing ever but it's not. It clear that the developers put a lot more heart and soul into it then... other games *cough* Call of Duty *cough* and i would love to see a game like this with a lot more random events. But The Yawhg just feels unfinished, both as a regular video game and as the party based experience it WANT'S to be. Meaning i can't recomend playing 10 or even 1 dollers on The Yawhg, becing as it clearly shouldn't be a paid product.  Nice art though.

A delightfully charming 2-4 player 'choose your adventure' game. It can be played by just one person, you then control 2 to 4 characters for each of the weeks, or up to 4 people can control an individual character.  In essence, you select a character and send them to a location each 'week'. There you will get a random event with two choices, which will have a certain effect on the character that can increase or decrease stats. At the end of the game, the last choice you make is weighed against the stats to see what happens.  Where this game shines however is in how everything interacts. The choices are fairy-tale like whimsical, and as you play it you realise everything interconnects, so you are actually building a short but internally coherent story, that can be different every time.  The game also has a really beautiful and fitting soundtrack. It is not offered on Steam alas, but you can find it on Bandcamp. I definitely recommend picking it up, too.  HOWEVER, and it's potentially big problem for the full price -- the game is short. You will have seen almost all it has to offer in four or five ten-minute playthroughs. At the current discounted price of 50% I can recommend it, but it just falls short of a recommendation at the full cost.
I was just expecting more I guess. Doesn't make it a bad game, but it might make it a short experience.

Just to be clear so people don't get the wrong idea, this game has about 10 minutes worth of gameplay, and can easily be beaten in 2 playthroughs. The game consists of 7 turns for 2 or more characters in which you choose a location, an action, and then maybe a binary choice or two at a random event.  The charm of the art and music and writing don't really make up for the fact that there isn't really a game here. This game should be a $3 or $5 purchase at most.
Lovely art but in no way does this justify its price tag.

Played two complete games in 15 minutes, with a lot of repeat events on the second playthrough. Game is hella short, is what I'm ever so subtly implying. You can basically go through most of the content in half an hour or so, including all the endings.  I guess it was advertised as a party game, but it doesn't have online co-op, and are you seriously going to invite people over to play hot-seat steam game?   The writing is just about 'passably amusing' at that.

This game is tricky to recommend. On the one hand, it has about 100 minutes of gameplay, tops. On the other hand, it is an interesting and cohesive use of the medium to convey a specific idea. It uses a 'choose your own adventure' style to allow each character you play to conduct different activities over the course of 6 turns. These activites grant or remove stats, and the stats you have determine how your character responds to different random events. At the end of the game, the stats help determine various outcomes for your character. It's a very, very simple and limited interface. However, the game is less interested in providing a compelling story than it is in demonstrating how the choices we make in life accumulate and ultimately create a story for us that makes sense only in retrospect. The relative meaninglessness of the stats in the game reflects the meaninglessness of our 'stats' in our lives. At the end of the day, our lives are equally defined by choices and events beyond our control, and these both with have impacts on our lives and also the life of the community we inhabit. In conveying this idea, the gameplay and themes of this game are in perfect harmony and it makes for a memorable experience.

A compelling interactive narrative with simple play, clever style, and interesting decisions to make. Very short, but everyone should play it at least twice: Once to figure out how it works, and a second time to try to save the town. Both run throughs together should take about an hour.  After that, you'll be done with it. There isn't much replay value here. After only afew playthroughs it becomes pretty clear where all the decisions are, and how they effect the outcome.

The Yawhg is a game of stories, stories that the player travels through randomly, forever hoping that they will survive the eponymous disaster. I shall not beat around the bush here. The gameplay in The Yawhg is incredibly minimal, with the only real player input being what actions the characters take during the six week ingame cycle. The game instead focuses heavily on the story and world interactions your choices create. The in depth details in The Yawhg are astounding with many in-game events big and small, hidden in obscure event pathways, based entirely on the skills you have bult up for your characters. But because of skill and day limitations it may become extremely tiresome for many players to try and see some of the Yawhgs more inner secrets, as they may accidentally trigger a event to occur earlier than they wished, or even a different event than what is wished for to occur. The main thing to keep in mind though when purchasing this game is this: Do you have any friends who live near you? If yes then The Yawhg is a great game to play as its couch co-op focus can make for a fun and eventful time. If not and you also have no means of streaming events to friends and playing that way, you will find yourself playing a game for four on your ownsome, and as fun as the game can be, playing it by yourself can be a very tiresome experience. Basically buy this game if you like fun storytelling and have friends.

This game is a fantastic fun game for a few hours of complete enjoyment. It has a few great twists and amazing features that you never might have thought would exist, as well as a branching storyline wich effects your and other players decisions and options throughout the storyline.
Enjoyable and short party game, however, you should probably buy it on sale. If you would like to see it before you buy it, look up Draxr and orc party up on youtube.
Great for small groups of people or just solo fun.  Great Soundtrack. Art is on point. However there are a few typos that take away from the overall experience. 5/7

Great if you need a few minutes to kill on a study or work break or something

The Yawhg is such a simple concept for a game, yet it has such a delightful art style along with an ever compromising story. I've played it countless times with and without others, and I almost always have a different outcome every time. It can be a little creepy, a little cute, very witty, and even sometimes pretty shocking. It's not typically for hardcore gamers, but I'll definitely recommend it to anyone who just wants to relax and take a few short journeys into the city with the disastrous, ever looming Yawhg.

I reccomend this game with two caveats. You can't play it alone, and you have to accept that 'bad' ends are fun too. That said, it's otherwise a ton of fun.  Definately needs more content, and if that isn't delivered (via DLC or free updates) it won't last long. Still, I got my money's worth with what is there.
A unique and original game that's fun to play alone but better to play with company.

Everyone grab a drink and gather around the couch; it's time to play The Yawhg.  In the vast sea of choose-your-own-adventure games out there, why are so few multiplayer? Why do so many forego gorgeous illustrations and lovingly hand-lettered title cards for plain black-on-white text? Why do so few have the brief playtime that makes for a perfect party game? Why do none of them have you cast the deciding vote in an election for a rat president?  The Yawhg succeeds on all of these fronts. It's also solidly, but not perfectly replayable (as you'll run into many events again on repeat plays). I only wish that there were more cooperative CYOAs like it. Developers, take note.
With out a doubt, my game of the year.
A really good text based role playing game, the world is in greate need of more games like this

I find this game to be fun but, quick. the only problem I have with it is lack of volume control.
A delightfully short game but the story is so malleable that it has a ton on replay value it is also great fun and hilarious to play with friends.

This game is a completly randomised experience every time, and the halirious events that can happen make you want to keep playing. I would recommend this to people who can play it with their friends and see what ending their characters get!

This is such a fantastic game! Don't you dare be put off by the low price or the people saying it's too short. This is a game that one can simply stop playing.  It has a fun, comedy board game style that will make you nostalgic and feel happy. The music is beautiful, and to top all that off there's the one unique point of this game that is done so well:  It's not about getting to the end, it's about enjoying what you have whilst you still have it. That, my friends, is a fantastic message about life. You're playing a fable! You simply don't lose the game.   Now, people will play it for different reasons. At first, you play it to make sure there's a good ending. Overtime, you get this idea that actually it's not about that. You make moral choices, you choose your fate. What your character becomes is a reflection of how you play it, and trust me, there's some really great twists and turns to the game.  My favourite part is that what one player does directly influences what happens to the other, thus making it a team game. Play with your friends, play with yourself, it's fun both ways for different reasons. Top game of the season, game of the year so far for me.   So, what are you waiting for? Buy it!

If your looking for a light-hearted, fun, and story-heavy game, this is gonna be your jam. It's not revolutionary and it's easy to win once you know how, but it's still a good time. It's very much meant to be played with friends though so streaming it or playing it while hanging out with someone is how you get the most bang for your buck. Also, while the little vignettes get repeatitive quickly, they are sometimes interconnected witch is nice. For example, you can humilate the bard by rocking harder than he can and then have another character find him hanging from a tree in shame.
This Game Is Fun I Would Suggest Playing It When Friends Are Over Though, And It's Not Woth 10 dollars 6/10

This is a game with a great concept that could have been executed in much more detail and grandiocity. The animation is nice though. I'd say this game is worth $0.50. Wait for a sale, no achievements for the game as well in case that's something important to you.

While rich in story and offering many different stories to be told for up to 4 players, Yawhg still seems to fall short of the game that it could have potentially been. The game is essentially for 1-4 players, each taking their turn of where to go during the week, what to do at said location, and how you respond to a random event. This process lasts for several weeks, around 6 or 8 I believe, before the 'Yawhg' comes. After the Yawhg comes, the game sums up your ending randomly. While fun, witty, and comedic, the 'adventure' that players go through is drastically short and is merely based on week to week events rather than the accumulative story. For $9.99 I would say the game is extremely short (lasting around 5-15 minutes depending on how fast you can read) and I would recommend it as a nice steam summer sale pick up. Other positive notes include pretty artwork, interesting scenarios, and a short-lived entertaining adventure game. I would give it a 5 out of 10.

A beautiful example of interactive storytelling. The gameplay is minimal and each playthrough lasts only about 15 minutes, but each one is a wonderful experience. Somehow the results and epilogues manage humor or heartbreak in just a few sentences. It may be more art than game, but still it's a worthwhile experience. Content can be somewhat limited though, and I hope they add new scenarios over time.   I recommend this to anyone who enjoys narrative games. It also can be hilarious as a group activity.
This game is well worth the money. I just bought it on sale. tons of replayablility and humor to go along with it.

This game is certainly a blast! While it only has still images and text, it brings a good bit of humor into each and every action. It also has an assortment of endings which can keep people going for ages! Definitely replayable, and I certainly loved the art and music. The characters are diverse and can be melded into any shape the player wants! Definitely recommended.

Great fun, especially with friends. LOts of possibilities, although after a few games, there is little replayability. Still a great game, would recommend for an evening with friends. Also, amazing music!
This was pretty magical.

The Yawhg is a simple Choose Your Own Adventure that can be completed within 10 minutes. However, you have many different choices (2 characters, with 2 choices each per 'day') within those 10 minutes that provide a mix of simple stat improvements to setting up other events later into the story.  The music and art help cement the atmosphere both before and after the titular Yawhg arrives.  I would probably say the game is priced slightly higher than it should be as the content is fairly light on both time and depth.

Probably one of the more interesting gaming experiences I've had in a while - playthroughs are quite short (anywhere from 15 minutes to an hour, depending on how many of you are playing and how much you discuss the going-ons), but this isn't a game you play once and then forget about, you keep returning to see what other ridiculous scenarios your people encounter.  Had several moments of incredible highs and deep lows while playing with flatmates, even encountering a strangely sinister ending for one character while everyone else spent their days making shoes and whatnot.  Anyway, if you want a nice experience to have with a few friends occasionally, you can't go far wrong with this - just don't expect to be learning any complex button combos or anything!

The yawhg as a game is very much like a board game. Every day you gather stats by visiting many locations of the city, with an immense amount of different things that can happen. After 6 weeks you choose what you want to do with those skills you`ve garnered, and depending on them, you decide the towns fate.  The main meat of the game however are the immense amount of different endings. You might have angered someone you shouldn`t have during the 6 weeks. You might have decided to do something you really shouldn`t have at the end. Maybe you turn into a monster yourself! ...Or maybe you live mostly an ordinary life.   The game in itself is best when played as a group. The game allows up to 4 players to go live in the town. The games biggest downfall is the fact, that it doesn`t support online multiplayer, but that is easily fixed with a call with skype as one person reads the choices out loud and does the choices for the other players like a game master.  Overall, if you want a fun experience, which most likely gives you an unique ending everytime if you aren`t afraid to try something new, and you like reading, buy the game.

A beautiful game in all regards. A simple concept - you make choices for characters that have various effects and determine the outcome of the game. A concept that could easily be poorly done, boring, uninspiring. But The Yawhg is none of those things. Each game session is short - about ten minutes - a length that feels right, yet also leaves you (me) wanting more. So I play it again, this time making different decisions. And then again. And again. Were I to classify this game, it would be interactive fiction, or rather, interactive storytelling. Storytelling, to me, isn't as detached as 'fiction.' A storyteller is there, talking to you, weaving a story, involving you in a different way than fiction (and I mean reading fiction when I say fiction). Both inspire your imagination and involve you in the story, but one - to me - is more personal, one makes you feel more like you helped tell the story. Thus why I think interactive storytelling is more fitting. The gameplay is sort of like ... simulation games that involve making a choice of what you do that week from various tasks, each one of them raising certaain stats . Princess Maker 2, Long Live the Queen, Spirited Heart -- games that have similar gameplay in that regard - but The Yawhg is not like any of those games in other respects. Just the mechanic of picking an activity that raises (or lowers sometimes) stats.  At the end of the game, depending on the events that happened, you find out what your choices ultilmately lead to. What consequences or benefits they had. And you're told about the effects on the individual characters as well.  That's a pretty rough descripton of the The Yawhg. Not because I described it poorly, but no decritption can convey the experience of this game. I loved the art style and find it very fitting for the themes and story. I loved he writing, which this focusing on story telling, that's a good thing to love. Every aspect is equal in quality and the quality is outstanding. I'm stating this so it's clear I am not intending to say anyone is more responsible for The Yawhg being the work of art that it is. I love music. Music is key for me when it comes to developing atmosphere and evoking emotions. So with that in mind, the music of The Yawhg is so well done. I loved everything about the score (and the game, like I said, I'm music oriented, so think of this is being for all those people who thrive off music. I know people who thrive off writing in the same way I thrive off music, and I can tell you every aspect of this game is in harmony and I hope if the deveopers were to read this, that it wouldn't come across as me downplaying all the oher aspects of the game. Super important to me, obviously, which is why I keep restating it.)  The song that plays during the end sequence is ... I can't imagine a song that would sound more fitting. It's a beautiful song and ...   All I can say is, if you like storytelling and interactive fiction/storytelling, and can enjoy a game that is short (but has a lot of replayability), I recommend this game with every recommending bone (it's a thing..) in my body. It's a work of art and everyone who worked on this -- I thank you for making this and giving it (releasing) to the world to experience and enjoy and if all of you decide to colloborate again - I'll buy whatever you make. And I'll be watching out for projects in general that involve any of the developers/etc that worked on this game.   IN SHORT, I give this the highest recommendation I can.

If someone had told me that they were thinking of making a short-form, story-focused party game that styles itself after choose your own adventure books, I would have advised them to find a better use of their time. Thankfully, the creators of The Yawhg did not receive or did not listen to such advice.  Each playthrough requires the player(s) to select at least two of the four available characters. The characters are unaware that the Yawhg, a fabled source of great destruction, is coming their way. The players get to decide how these unsuspecting characters spend their last six weeks: select one of eight locations and one of two actions for that character to take part in during that week. The chosen action, along with random events that might trigger, will alter the character's stats. One characters' actions might trigger or help explain events encountered by other characters; they might even begin a questline that can be followed or ignored.  The game has multiple endings based on all of these factors. Although there are a limited number of permutations, enough can happen that no single playthrough has felt the same as another. This is an excellent game, and I hope to see others like it.

When I'm over at a friend's house and i introduce this game, friends tend to be very reluctant. 'The Yog? Th fuq is dis shet?' but after convincing and non-consensual involvement in gameplay, there is always laughter and merriment to ensue.   The Yawhg is a fantastic game for up to four friends. Sometimes you start to notice some repetition but there is plenty of variation available. It is very simple to follow and good way to get people in a good mood or distracted from their bad mood.   I personally love the game because I like to watch my friends interact in the this unique world set in a pre-apocolyptic short adventure while I narrate and voice the various characters.   The game itself is basically the backstory for your character that effects the various character traits (charisma, mind, wealth, ect.) that help play your roll after the Yawhg arrives, a all-destroying natural disaster in which you and few others survive. the end of the games tells you how you fair after the distruction settles. Good or bad, it is painted on a canvas with light-heartedness that kind makes you say 'well alrighty then.'  It's a small game great for passing time with friends but its not a 7-hour-plus rpg. games last between 5-20 mins. One thing is for sure, the writers wanted you to be surprised around every corner so don't expect a boring game... beacuse... well, you won't get one... This is an unique kind of party game that you don't find anywhere else. Rather than a party game where you have mindless fun and game, this is a game where you and your friends take on a role and roleplay together. As such, it is a really good roleplay game, where all of the actions have direct or/and indirect consequences and changes the outcome of the game. With every playthrough, every decision and consequences differs, and so every playthrough is unique in it's own way. The art-style is nice, the music (albeit repetitive) suits the mood, the gameplay is simple and engaging, and when played with friends, i have no doubt that it'll be a fun party game, possibly even better when drunk.  As a single player game however, it completely lacks any kind of weight. This is the reason why i cannot recommend this to anyone who does not have a friend to play couch co-op with, because that is the only way this game is meant to be played. 0.2 hours is all that it takes for me to finish one playthrough, and that's with me reading every single text. It's really short, really shallow as well, and does not leave a lasting impression. Like i mentioned before, this game is meant to be played with other people, who will contribute their own depths to the story. Playing it alone however, means that there's nothing much to do, except absentmindedly pick choices and read the consequences, alone.  I want to love this game, because this kind of game with choices, branching story, consequences that impacts the story, and character building, but there's not enough for me to love about this game  TL;DR if you have someone to go couch co-op with, i would recommend buying it. If you don't have, don't buy this.
